t: Job 27
Job Maintains His Integrity
Moreover*p Job continued his discourse, and said:
“As*ipn God lives, who*i has taken away my justice, And*ld the Almighty, who*i has made my soul bitter,
As*ld long as my breath is*i in me, And*ld the breath of God in my nostrils,
My*ld lips will not speak wickedness, Nor*ld my tongue utter deceit.
Far*ld be it from me That*ld I should say you are right; Till*ld I die I will not put away my integrity from me.
My*ld righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go; My*ld heart shall not reproach me*i as long as I live.
“May*ln my enemy be like the wicked, And*ld he who rises up against me like the unrighteous.
For*ld what is the hope of the hypocrite, Though*ld he may gain much,*i If*ld God takes away his life?
Will*ld God hear his cry When*ld trouble comes upon him?
Will*ld he delight himself in the Almighty? Will*ld he always call on God?
“I*ln will teach you about the hand of God; What*ld is*i with the Almighty I will not conceal.
Surely*ld all of you have seen it;*i Why*ld then do you behave with complete nonsense?
“This*ln is the portion of a wicked man with God, And*ld the heritage of oppressors, received from the Almighty:
If*ld his children are multiplied, it*i is*i for the sword; And*ld his offspring shall not be satisfied with bread.
Those*ld who survive him shall be buried in death, And*ld their widows shall not weep,
Though*ld he heaps up silver like dust, And*ld piles up clothing like clay—
He*ld may pile it*i up, but the just will wear it,*i And*ld the innocent will divide the silver.
He*ld builds his house like a moth, Like*ld a booth which*i a watchman makes.
The*ld rich man will lie down, But*ld not be gathered up;*i He*ld opens his eyes, And*ld he is*i no more.
Terrors*ld overtake him like a flood; A*ld tempest steals him away in the night.
The*ld east wind carries him away, and he is gone; It*ld sweeps him out of his place.
It*ld hurls against him and does not spare; He*ld flees desperately from its power.
Men*ild shall clap their hands at him, And*ld shall hiss him out of his place.
